title: How to Take Care of a Shaved Head for Women

steps.title: Dirt and oil can build up on your shaved scalp, so don’t skip the shampoo.
steps.content: Dirt and oil can build up on your shaved scalp, so don’t skip the shampoo. Choose a shampoo that’s labeled as “moisturizing.” Apply a dime-size dollop of shampoo to your palm, then massage it onto your scalp. Rinse away the suds with warm water. [1] X Research source ​ If you shaved your head during cancer treatment, use a gentle, fragrance-free shampoo like baby shampoo to wash your scalp. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Dandruff can cause dull, flaky patches on your bald scalp.
steps.content: Dandruff can cause dull, flaky patches on your bald scalp. Fortunately, this is an easy problem to fix! Wash your hair with dandruff shampoo twice a week if you're of Caucasian or Asian descent or once a week if you're of African descent. Use regular shampoo the other days you wash. [3] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Make sure you read the directions on your dandruff shampoo so you use it correctly. Some shampoos must be left on your scalp for several minutes, while others should be rinsed off immediately.

steps.title: Your scalp and new hair growth both benefit from moisture.
steps.content: Your scalp and new hair growth both benefit from moisture. Apply a quarter-size dollop of conditioner to your hand and massage it onto your scalp. Let it sit for about 30 seconds, then rinse it off with warm water. [4] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Choose a conditioner that’s labeled as “moisturizing.” If you’re going through cancer treatment, choose a conditioner that’s fragrance-free.

steps.title: A shaved head is more prone to dryness and irritation.
steps.content: A shaved head is more prone to dryness and irritation. Fortunately, you can easily maintain soft, smooth skin. Use a regular moisturizer if you want a shiny scalp, or pick a lotion that's labeled as "mattifying" if you want to avoid shine. [5] X Research source Apply your moisturizer daily after your shower or when you're getting ready for bed. [6] X Research source Use a water-based moisturizer if your skin is neither dry nor oily. Pick an oil-based moisturizer for dry skin, or a light-weight water-based lotion for oily skin. [7] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you're going through cancer treatments, choose a moisturizer that doesn't contain fragrances. If your head is really dry and irritated, apply moisturizer more than once a day. For instance, you might moisturize your head after your morning shower and right before bed.

steps.title: You might prefer to use oils instead of moisturizers.
steps.content: You might prefer to use oils instead of moisturizers. Oils can also help you maintain a soft, healthy scalp. Use oil daily to lock in moisture after a shower. [8] X Research source Squeeze a dot of oil onto your palm, then massage it into your scalp using your fingertips. Moroccan oil is a great option! [9] X Research source Alternatively, try castor oil if you want to stimulate hair growth. [10] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You can use oil in addition to moisturizer if your skin gets very dry. It's really up to you!

steps.title: Your scalp sweats, and you don't have hair to soak it up.
steps.content: Your scalp sweats, and you don't have hair to soak it up. Luckily, there’s an easy way to stay dry. Every night before bed, swipe an antiperspirant over the top of your head once or twice. The product will soak into your scalp overnight so you'll stay fresh all day. [11] X Research source You can use the same kind of antiperspirant as you would for your underarms.

steps.title: A scalp massage helps keep your scalp healthy.
steps.content: A scalp massage helps keep your scalp healthy. Do the massage in the shower or while applying moisturizer or oil. Start by placing your fingers just above your forehead. Apply light pressure, then start making circular movements with your fingers. Work your way from your forehead to the nape of your neck. [12] X Research source Massaging your scalp may also help stimulate hair growth.

steps.title: Your exposed scalp is vulnerable to sunburn, so always wear sunscreen.
steps.content: Your exposed scalp is vulnerable to sunburn, so always wear sunscreen. Both creamy and spray sunscreens work great on your scalp. Choose a broad-spectrum sunscreen that’s at least an SPF 30. Wear your sunscreen every day, no matter the season. If you're spending the day outdoors, reapply sunblock every 2 hours to keep your scalp protected. [13] X Research source Carry sunscreen in your bag so you always have it on hand. If you wear a hat or scarf, you can skip the sunscreen.

steps.title: Your exposed scalp is more vulnerable to the sun.
steps.content: Your exposed scalp is more vulnerable to the sun. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Go with a wide-brim hat for more protection, or throw on a baseball cap for an easy option. Alternatively, pick a stylish hat or scarf that goes with your outfit. The options are endless! [15] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Darker hats might protect you from the sun better. Make sure the hat you choose doesn’t have an open weave, since the sun can filter through the gaps. For instance, straw hats often have gaps in the weave. [16] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Cold weather can chill your shaved head.
steps.content: Cold weather can chill your shaved head. Stay comfortable by covering your head before you go out. [17] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Choose a hooded jacket or coat for an easy option. Go with a fun hat for a stylish solution, or wear a classic beanie for a cozy winter look. It’s a myth that you lose more heat through your head than other exposed areas. However, it’s still important to wear a hat. [18] X Trustworthy Source University of Rochester Medical Center Leading academic medical center in the U.S. focused on clinical care and research Go to source If you live in a really cold area, you might wear both a beanie and a hood. You can always take your hat off indoors if you want to show off your shaved head.

steps.title: Protect your skin from nicks and irritation with shaving cream.
steps.content: Protect your skin from nicks and irritation with shaving cream. Shave after a shower or splash water over your scalp to wet it. Then, add a dollop of shaving cream to your palm and smooth it over your scalp. This makes it easier for the razor to glide over your skin. [19] X Research source Wetting your skin and hair softens it so it’s easier to shave.

steps.title: This will prevent ingrown hairs and razor bumps.
steps.content: This will prevent ingrown hairs and razor bumps. Look at the way your hair grows before you drag your razor blade across your scalp. Always drag your razor across your scalp in this direction. Otherwise, you might end up with red bumps on your scalp. [20] X Research source Keep in mind that all of your hair may not grow in the same direction.

steps.title: A dull razor can irritate your skin.
steps.content: A dull razor can irritate your skin. Don’t use the same razor for too long. Instead, keep a supply of extra blades or disposable razors on hand so you can grab a new blade as needed. Typically, blades last for up to 7 shaves. [21] X Research source
